bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, September 6, 1950

div1.p: Hench informs Blossom Reed that he is making inquiries about the annuity to be paid her by the Walter Reed Memorial Association and discusses the possibility of using some of the fund's principal.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, September 6, 1950
div1.opener:
September 6, 1950
Mrs. Blossom Reed
Blue Ridge Summit
Pennsylvania
My dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
I am disturbed to hear of your concern. I do not know why you
have not heard officially from the trust fund. I know that arrangements were
to be made for the annuity previously given to your mother to be given to
you. I am at once making discreet inquiries and believe that you will in
the near future be properly informed.

I do not have with me at the moment the stipulations of the trust
but I seem to remember that some of the principal can be used as well as
the interest if the necessity is urgent. Of course the Association would
hate to lower the principal. You are at present and for the forseeable
future, the sole beneficiary of the fund and of course if the principal
is lowered the interest would also be lowered. However I appreciate
your expression of confidence in me by confiding to me of your needs. I
shall certainly try to help.

It is very gracious of you to suggest that I come into possession
of some of your mother's material. It is so difficult to discuss this by
letter. I expect to be in Washington fairly soon and will try to arranve
to visit you if at all possible. Perhaps that would be the best way.

In the meantime, be of courage because you have friends who are
interested in you and who appreciate very much the great loyalty and devotion
which you exhibited to your mother through the long years.
